title: Nurses transforming systems of care: The bicentennial of Florence Nightingale's legacy
abstract: This paper explores the impact of Florence Nightingale's legacy on the contemporary healthcare system. A review of primary sources from the 19th century shows us how Nurses have evolved their roles to become a decisive part of patient care during hospitalizations and beyond, transforming systems of care towards improved outcomes for patients.

title: How to use the MEROPS database and website to help understand peptidase specificity
abstract: This paper explores how to use the MEROPS database and website in order to acquire insight into peptidase specificity. Peptidases, or proteolytic enzymes, are ubiquitous across organisms and play multiple roles within biological systems such as hydrolyzing proteins for digestion and regulating gene expression. The MEROPS database is a comprehensive collection of knowledge on protease families that contains data from sequence alignments, active sites, structures and substrate preferences which allow researchers to efficiently understand their functionality. We will demonstrate how specific searches can give detailed information about particular enzyme classes whilst highlighting limitations of certain tools available on the website. This methodology provides an accessible resource for users looking to discover more about peptidases and take advantage of potential applications in a variety of scientific fields including biology and biochemistry.

title: Rash and Elevated Creatine Kinase in a Deployed Soldier
abstract: This paper presents the case of a deployed soldier who experienced rash, along with an elevated creatine kinase. An extensive diagnostic algorithm revealed that the cause was primary Erythema Multiforme, complicated by Myositis Ossificans and Fibrosis. Diagnostic criteria and parameters are discussed in light of the patient's clinical presentation. Additionally, laboratory investigations revealed that his creatine kinase levels exceeded 2,000 U/L after sustained activity involving marching drills in hot weather while wearing full military gear. This report delineates and highlights the importance of early diagnosis to prevent further progression of this disease entity to avoid complications and impairments amongst individuals suffering from primary erythema multiforme.

title: Vitamin D supplementation protects against reductions in plasma 25‐hydroxyvitamin D induced by open‐heart surgery: Assess‐d trial
abstract: This abstract presents the findings of the Assess-d trial, a randomized clinical study assessing vitamin D supplementation for use as a protective agent for reducing reductions in plasma 25‐hydroxyvitamin D levels induced by open‐heart surgery. The placebo-controlled trial was conducted on 128 participants with a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction about to undergo cardiac revascularization procedures. It found that compared to placebo, weekly oral supplementation with 40 000 IU (1000 mcg) of vitamin D3 had significant beneficial effects protecting against reductions of up to 30% in plasma 25‐hydroxyvitamin D level at 3 months after surgery. Marked differences were also observed in other secondary measures including improved cardio muscle strength and significantly lower cardiovascular disease risks associated with preoperative deficiency or insufficiency states. These results support the use of vitamin D supplementation as an effective therapy to protect against adverse outcomes following cardiac revascularization, offering possible implications both for preventive medicine and clinical healthcare delivery.

title: Experimental parameters defining ultra-low biomass bioaerosol analysis
abstract: This study addresses the Experimental parameters defining ultra-low biomass bioaerosol analysis and presents a roadmap for its evaluation. In recent times, awareness of air pollution has grown immensely resulting in an increased interest in research involving bioaerosols. With advances made in aerosol science, it has now become possible to analyze these particles down to nanometer scales using techniques such as spectroscopy, chromatography, and microscopy. This research considers different aspects related to testing methods of elemental constituents present at ultratrace level within these bioaerosols like hygroscopic growth factors (HGFs), particle size distribution (PSD) and Total Organic Carbon TOC concentrations that are necessary for analyses but often neglected due to their low biomass amount which makes them difficult to detect accurately by traditional analytical techniques. The purpose of this paper is to develop new strategies based on experimental parameters that can improve the efficiency of ultra-low biomass bioaerosol detection making reliable results accessible with greater accuracy than before.

title: Branching out
abstract: This paper examines the effects of 'branching out', which represents a strategy linking individuals, teams and entire organizations to gain wider perspectives in problem-solving contexts. We explore potential benefits from venturing beyond homogeneous environments to become more diverse and innovative.

title: An extraordinary year
abstract: This study examines the unique challenges posed by 2020, an extraordinary year that brought unprecedented change for individuals and society. The impact of the global pandemic on multiple domains is discussed in detail - from education, to health care systems and economic stability.

title: Influence of Inhalation Injury on Incidence, Clinical Profile and Recovery Pattern of Dysphagia Following Burn Injury
abstract: This article investigates the correlation between inhalation injury and its influence on dysphagia after burn injuries. Dysphagia can lead to several clinically adverse effects, so understanding how to prevent it is of paramount importance. Data from a cohort study was gathered from 21 patients who were treated for both burn and inhalation injuries at a major Chinese university hospital over the past five years. Medical records were examined to analyse degree of burns, length of stay in ICU, incidence rate, clinical features, as well as recovery pattern of post-burn dysphagia. Results showed that there was a significant difference in all measured variables when compared with those who did not suffer an inhalation injury; notably higher incidence rate and longer length of stay in ICU could be observed. Based on this data, the findings suggest that if proper precautions will be taken such as fast recognition and early treatment of BII during burn care process by clinicians may help reduce incidences associated with dysphasia following burn trauma.

title: Human Cardioviruses, Meningitis, and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome in Children
abstract: This paper examines the role of human cardioviruses in relation to meningitis and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). With an increasing rate of SIDS, it is important to understand the impact that viruses may have on children. This study will explore the potential linkage between viral infections and immunological factors associated with these fatal illnesses in young children. By identifying connections between viral loads and physiological parameters in a clinical dataset, we can identify ways to reduce development or risk of complications from such conditions.

title: SARS may be here to stay
abstract: This paper examines emergent SARS-CoV2 epidemiology, inflammation studies, and laboratory analyses to provide evidence that suggests the virus may persist in a persistent state. Examined are potential implications for public policy, resource allocation and present countermeasures for limiting transmission.

title: Noninvasive Mechanical Ventilation in Patients with Acute Respiratory Failure Due to Pandemic Influenza A(H1N1) Virus
abstract: This paper describes the usage of noninvasive mechanical ventilation in patients with acute respiratory failure due to pandemic influenza A(H1N1) virus. The efficacy, safety, and tolerability of this approach when compared to conventional invasive techniques are analyzed through a review of recent case studies. We also discuss practical implementations that could reduce critical care requirements for hospitalized substance abusers during a widespread epidemic.

title: Relationship between circulating levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2-angiotensin-(1–7)-MAS axis and coronary heart disease
abstract: This paper examines the intricate relationship between circulating levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2)-angiotensin-(1–7)-MAS axis and coronary heart disease (CHD). Recent evidence suggests that ACE2 may play a role in modulating the risk of cardiovascular diseases. In particular, higher expression of ACE2 has been associated with decreased cardiovascular mortality in animal models. Furthermore, current studies indicate that the dynamic action of ACE2 may be mediated by its control over Ang(1–7)/Mas receptor/effector gene expression. This study seeks to evaluate how disrupted circulatory profiles for each component within this system may contribute to extensive CHD pathology, as well as elucidate potential therapeutic interventions that target these components through regulation or enhancement of their participatory roles. Examining literature and clinical data from a variety of populations worldwide, it is hypothesized in this paper that cutting-edge approaches targeting dysregulated components within the ACE2-Ang(1–7)-Mas system could have a significant impact on reducing morbidity due to coronary heart disease.

title: Inhibitory Effect and Possible Mechanism of Action of Patchouli Alcohol against Influenza A (H2N2) Virus
abstract: This paper examines the inhibitory effects of patchouli alcohol against Influenza A (H2N2) virus and investigates its potential mechanism of action. Patchouli alcohol, derived from Pogostemon cablin, is a major component of essential oils and has been reported as having antiviral activity against various types of bacteria. In this study, MTT assays were performed to determine the cytotoxicity of patchouli alcohol at different concentrations followed by in vitro infection with H2N2 influenza virus on Vero cells in the presence or absence of patchouli alcohol. The results indicate that patchouli alcohol inhibited H2N2 replication without causing any adverse effects on cell morphology or viability suggesting it can potentially be used for treatment purposes. Further evaluations were carried out to analyze whether apoptosis mediates the antiviral effect through caspase 3/7 activation experiments; these results showed no significant expression variation when compared with control cells indicating an alternative mechanism is involved at play hereinr. In conclusion, this research provides evidence that patchouli alcohol may be beneficial in treating Influenza A (H2N2).

title: Challenges in modelling complexity of fungal entomopathogens in semi-natural populations of insects
abstract: This study aims to explore the complexity of fungal entomopathogens in semi-natural populations of insects. While advances have been made in recent years, significant challenges remain for developing accurate models that express this intricate web of interactions between fungi and their insect hosts. This research defines the scope for emerging technologies and improved theoretical approaches to overcome current limitations and provide more comprehensive predictive models. By providing an overview of both current studies as well as future possibilities, this paper may guide the development of informatics applied to myconto-entomological studies, particularly those in the field of semi-natural population monitoring and disease control.

title: The Impact of US Nurses’ Personal Religious and Spiritual Beliefs on Their Mental Well-Being and Burnout: A Path Analysis
abstract: This paper investigates the effect of nurses’ personal religious and spiritual beliefs on their mental well-being and burnout in a sample of US nurses. Utilizing path analysis, results found that an individual's spiritual belief is associated with greater mental health functioning but increased likelihood for experiencing burnout. Implications for training initiatives and nursing practice are discussed to encourage empathy, self-care and resilience among nurses during stressful periods.

title: Mannose-binding lectin deficiency and acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
abstract: This paper examines the potential association between mannose-binding lectin deficiency and acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Mannose-binding lectin is a circulating protein that mediates innate immunity. Recent literature suggests an impaired capability for recognition of microbial stimuli in patients with COPD, which has led to speculation that Mannose-binding lectin may contribute to the pathophysiology of acute exacerbations of COPD. The objective of this work was to evaluate the relationship between Mannose-binding lectin levels and risk for COPD exacerbation among individuals with moderate or severe forms of the condition. A prospective study encompassing 190 outpatients from two hospitals identified through chart review was conducted wherein participants completed clinical assessments as well as lab testing at baseline and every one month interval for up to 12 months. Primary outcome analysis demonstrated that fewer participants who were diagnosed with both COPD and had deficient levels of Mannose-binding lectin experienced acute cohort exacerbations than those without similarly diminished MBL levels. title: Nucleolar-nucleoplasmic shuttling of TARG1 and its control by DNA damage-induced poly-ADP-ribosylation and by nucleolar transcription
abstract: This research article introduces the novel discovery of a newly identified mechanism that governs the nucleolar-nucleoplasmic shuttling of TARG1 in response to DNA damage-induced poly-ADP ribosylation and nucleolar transcription. By combining quantitative mass spectrometry, biochemical isolation techniques as well as nuclear subfractionation and live cell imaging approaches, we were able to demonstrate how TARG1 forms clusters at sites of DNA damage-induced poly ADP ribosylation before relocating itself into the nucleolus where it is transcribed. Subsequent investigation revealed that these processes are further controlled by signaling pathways such as ATM/ATR and p53 dependent pathways understood to integrate cellular stress responses through phosphorylation cascades. Our findings thus highlight an important role for TARG1 in dynamic mechanisms which govern intracellular identity during fast adaptation to stressful situations encountered within a given environment.

this research article introduces the novel discovery of a newly identified mechanism that governs the nucleolarnucleoplasmic shuttling of targ1 in response to dna damageinduced polyadp ribosylation and nucleolar transcription by combining quantitative mass spectrometry biochemical isolation techniques as well as nuclear subfractionation and live cell imaging approaches we were able to demonstrate how targ1 forms clusters at sites of dna damageinduced poly adp ribosylation before relocating itself into the nucleolus where it is transcribed subsequent investigation revealed that these processes are further controlled by signaling pathways such as atmatr and p53 dependent pathways understood to integrate cellular stress responses through phosphorylation cascades our findings thus highlight an important role for targ1 in dynamic mechanisms which govern intracellular identity during fast adaptation to stressful situations encountered within a given environment

title: Identification of 2-(4-(Phenylsulfonyl)piperazine-1-yl)pyrimidine Analogues as Novel Inhibitors of Chikungunya Virus
abstract: This study aimed to identify 2-(4-(Phenylsulfonyl)piperazine-1-yl)pyrimidine analogues as novel small molecule inhibitors of Chikungunya Virus (CHIKV). Following extensive analysis and evaluations, the evaluation and comparison of potency, selectivity and cytotoxicity of a set of newly synthesized compounds revealed that they could be leveraged as potent inhibitors against CHIKV replication. Consequently, we report the discovery and identification of 2-(4-(Phenylsulfonylists piperazine-1=yl)pyrimidine analogues as worthy candidates for further research on CHIKV antiviral treatments.

title: Problem- and Case-Based Learning in Science: An Introduction to Distinctions, Values, and Outcomes
abstract: This article investigates the efficacy of Problem- and Case-Based Learning (PCBL) in science education. The emergence of PCBL comes out of an increasing recognition that many scientific domains require students to effectively apply knowledge, solve problems, and think critically; in other words, to develop skills beyond mere recall. This paper sets out to explore the distinctions between traditional rote learning techniques and those used by PCBL curricula. It will consider their respective values for scientific instruction as well as outcomes these approaches have on student performance from both quantitative and qualitative perspectives.

title: Biological response modifiers and infectious diseases: Actual and potential therapeutic agents
abstract: This paper focuses on the current understanding of how biological response modifiers, such as cytokines and antimicrobial peptides interact with infectious diseases in humans. It reviews the immune responses of these agents which can directly and indirectly modulate host resistance against pathogenic invaders, as well as their anti-inflammatory potential during infection. This study investigates both actual therapeutic agents commonly used to combat these infections, such as antibiotics and immunomodulatory compounds, and novel potential therapeutic options that are currently being explored. Finally, future studies will be proposed which should evaluate the safety and efficacy of these new treatments in combating a variety of untreated or inadequately treated diseases caused by various microorganisms.

title: Rotaviral Diarrhea
abstract:
Rotaviral Diarrhea: The Impact and Prevalence of Rotavirus Infection in Children Under 5 
This paper provides a comprehensive examination of rotavirus infection, its impact on children under the age of five, and the prevalence rates of this disease worldwide. Drawing from primary and secondary sources alike, we analyze several concerning factors with respect to mortality, morbidity, hospitalization rates related to rotavirus and overall healthcare implications for reducing these figures. In doing so a clearer outlook is provided on the various aspects along with preventive measures for tackling this very common health issue.

title: Apoptosis in MHV-Induced Demyelination
abstract: This study investigates the involvement of apoptosis in murine hepatitis virus (MHV)-induced demyelination. Using a mouse model, the authors investigate whether or not there is an association between viral infection and apoptotic neurons. The findings suggest that MHV-mediated demyelination is associated with generated cytolysis due to excessive levels of programmed cell death by apoptosis. Therefore, this paper implies apoptosis as a necessary process for neuronal loss during MHV-induced neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Acute Chest Infections in Children
abstract: The current study investigates the prevalence of acute chest infections in children. It outlines the various categories of respiratory illnesses impacting this specific age group, as well as epidemiological data surrounding these medical conditions. There is a growing need to identify and address risk factors for respiratory infections in children, so effective intervention may be implemented to improve overall health outcomes.

title: Lack of Association between Toxocara Exposure and Suicide Attempts in Psychiatric Patients
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the lack of association between Toxocara exposure and suicide attempts in psychiatric patients. The aim was to evaluate whether a history of past Toxocara infection or serum immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody for Toxocara infection could serve as risk factors for suicidal behavior among this population. Data on clinical symptoms, IgG antibodies and depression scores were collected from patient records at two psychiatric centers in the United Kingdom, covering approximately 600 subjects aged 16-64 years. The results showed that although serum levels of IgG antibodies indicated previous exposure to Toxocara parasites, no link was found between this exposure and suicidal tendencies within this cohort. In conclusion, our findings do not support any causal relationship between Toxocara exposure and suicide attempts by these patients during their illness.

title: Strain-specific transcriptional and posttranscriptional regulation of heat-labile toxin expression by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
abstract: This study examines the strain-specific transcriptional and posttranscriptional regulation of heat-labile toxin expression by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC). Heat labile toxin (LT) is an endotoxin produced by ETEC, which is an important cause of gastroenteritis in humans. Tightly regulated LT expression has been determined to be a key factor for successful colonization of this bacterium within its host; however, it has not yet been fully clarified why certain strains are better colonizers than others. This work reviews recent findings on the regulatory mechanisms and environmental cues that influence strain-specific patterns of LT production and contributes to defining new approaches for controlling ETEC infection in humans.

abstract: This article explores the prevalence and causes of Nonneoplastic Pleural Disease. title: Identifying volatile metabolite signatures for the diagnosis of bacterial respiratory tract infection using electronic nose technology: A pilot study
abstract: This paper presents the preliminary results of a pilot study that evaluated the potential use of electronic-nose technology to identify volatile metabolite signatures for diagnosing bacterial respiratory tract infections (RTIs). Through its innovative approach, this study aimed to develop an alternative and cost-effective diagnostic technique capable of contributing to earlier detection, better management, and improved outcome. To this end, human subjects diagnosed with RTI were subjected to breath analysis using a miniature low-power spectroscopic gas sensor device. Initial findings suggest that by measuring volatiles associated with particular metabolic markers in exhaled air samples, it is possible to classify individuals according to disease status with high accuracy. The implications of these novel results indicate promising prospects for further exploring the application of eNose technology for acute health care diagnosis in general practice settings.

title: Genotype-Specific Detection of Ferret Coronavirus by Conventional and Real-Time Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction
abstract: This study aimed to investigate the applicability of conventional and real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) methods for the genotype-specific detection of ferret coronavirus (FCoV). As FCoV is a major cause of morbidity in this species, swift diagnosis and appropriate treatment are essential. Thus, through utilization of both RT-PCR techniques, two distinct FCoV genotypes were successfully identified, confirming their utility as powerful tools in the selective molecular identification of FCoV infection.

title: Vaccination of pregnant cows with K99 antigen of enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli and protection by colostrum in newborn calves
abstract: This article examines the impact of vaccinating pregnant cows with K99 antigen against enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli and subsequent protection provided by colostrum in newborn calves. The aims of this study were to investigate the efficacy of vaccination during pregnancy, as well as whether colostral antibodies would offer immunity for the duration that antibodies from maternal serum can be expected to last in their offspring. Results showed that not only did maternal immunization with K99 significantly protect calves born thereafter, providing potentially lasting effects up to one month after birth, but also highlighted a strong correlation between humoral immunity generated through colostrum ingestion and E. coli antibody titers at 5 weeks post-birth compared to control groups.

title: Studies of an outbreak of acute hepatitis A: II. Antibody changes to cytomegalovirus and herpesvirus
abstract: This study seeks to identify the potential link between acute hepatitis A and antibody changes for cytomegalovirus and herpesvirus. Using a sample of 350 patients, antibody levels were measured pre-and post-infection in order to understand clinical correlations. Results will help inform future clinical decisions regarding the diagnosis and management of co-occurring viral infections.

title: Weak evidence of country- and institution-related status bias in the peer review of abstracts
abstract: This paper examines weak evidence of status bias in the peer review process, specifically related to countries and institutions. Data from previous study results as well as comparing abstracts from different parts of the world and various universities were used to investigate this issue. The findings suggest that there may be a slight trend for certain academic affiliations to receive better or worse reviews compared with average scores. The implications these findings have on publishing processes are discussed in light of existing theories regarding implicit biases among peer reviewers.

title: Enhanced infection control interventions reduced catheter-related bloodstream infections in the neonatal department of Hung Vuong Hospital, Vietnam, 2011–2012: a pre- and post-intervention study
abstract: This article examines the impact of an enhanced infection control intervention implemented in the neonatal department at Hung Vuong Hospital, Vietnam, from 2011 to 2012. The study encompasses a pre- and post-intervention analysis. Data was prospectively collected on catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBSI) events such as Gram negative/positive bacteria isolated via quantitative blood cultures as well as antimicrobial susceptibilities. Overall, compared to the pre-intervention data CRBSI rates significantly decreased by 42%, suggesting this improved infection control program effectively reduced transmission and morbidity associated with antibiotic resistant pathogens in newborns cared for at Hung Vuong Hospital during the time period examined here. In conclusion, there is ample evidence that indicates following appropriate guidelines are paramount to successful infection prevention and may benefit other neonatal departments around the region similarly situated facing similar challenges.

title: CD4 rat × rat and mouse × rat T cell hybridomas produced by fusion of established T cell lines and clones to W/Fu (C58NT)D
abstract: This paper presents an innovative method of producing CD4 rat × rat and mouse × rat T cell hybridomas using the fusion of established T cell lines and clones to W/Fu (C58NT)D. Our study demonstrates successful hybridoma development through the combination of three different species, resulting in enhanced antigen-specific responses not previously achievable. The produced hybridomas were characterized for both level and quality for each respective marker in order to assess functionality as well as multilineage immunophenotypic capabilities. The results show that this novel approach can be used to produce a wide variety of functional hybridoma clones appropriate for anti-tumor as well as other immune response therapies.

title: Effect of down-regulating VEGF on proliferation of colon carcinoma cell HT-29
abstract: This paper focuses on the effect of down-regulating vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) on proliferation in colon carcinoma cell line HT-29. VEGF was thought to play a special role in cancer metastasis and angiogenesis; thus, decreasing its expression would enable us to observe how it affects cells. We conducted experiments using siRNA interference technique to suppress VEGF levels and proliferation rate were evaluated by MTT assay. The results suggested that reduction of VEGF could inhibit colony forming ability of HT-29 cells, particularly when combined with another gene targeting therapy. Our findings provide new insight into the potential therapeutic application of extending molecular or genetic therapies for colon carcinoma treatment by focusing on the regulation of tumor microenvironment mediated pathways associated with antiangiogenic proteins such as VEGF.

title: Assessing the Impact of Street-View Greenery on Fear of Neighborhood Crime in Guangzhou, China
abstract: The assessment of greenery in cities has gained traction as an environmental issue and risk factor analysis. This study focuses on the impact of street-view greenery on fear of neighborhood crime in Guangzhou, China. A total of 98 adults comprising 51 males and 47 females completed a survey to assess their self-reported fear after exposure to different levels of perceived street-view vegetation density observed from residential windows. Findings from this investigation show that street-view greenery significantly lowers mean self-reported fear ratings; however, leafy cover was found to be more prominently associated with decreased perceptions of neighborhood insecurity than other types such as shrubbery. Results point further explored the potential effects of urban forestry interventions in promoting active living by reducing residents' perception that neighborhoods can be risky environments for physical activity.

title: Mesenchymal stem/stromal cells: the therapeutic effects in animal models of acute pulmonary diseases
abstract: This article examines Mesenchymal stem/stromal cells (MSCs) as potential therapies for acute pulmonary diseases in animal models, which has not previously been a widely studied area. It is well-recognized that MSCs possess immuno-modulating properties, making them attractive candidates for treating respiratory diseases. In this study, the authors investigate how MSC therapy reduces inflammation and ameliorates lung injuries in an experimental model of inspiratory LPS challenge. Specifically, they analyze and compare their effects on reducing mortality rate with regard to cytokine levels - such as IL 6 and TNF α - as measured by qPCR analysis 24h after insult. The results indicate that treatment of mice with MSCs significantly reduce inflammation resulting from harms inflicted by infectious agents including LPS and augment survival rates compared to untreated mice. This novel research provides further evidence suggesting that MSC therapy may be effective to combat various types of acute pulmonary diseases both in humans and animals alike.

title: Role of viruses in etiology and pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis
abstract: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a debilitating demyelinating disease of the central nervous system that affects approximately 2.4 million people worldwide. Its etiology remains largely unknown, but it has been suggested in recent years that viruses may play an important role in pathogenesis and progression of MS. This review article will provide a synopsis on current evidence regarding the potential involvement of viruses such as Epstein-Barr virus and human herpes virus 6 as possible triggers for MS as well as how they interact with other contributing factors to exacerbate this disorder. Furthermore, future research directions and clinical implications on these findings will be discussed throughout this analysis. The title of this study is "Role Of Viruses In Etiology And Pathogenesis Of Multiple Sclerosis", which intends to explore the hypothesis that pathogens could bring about neurological changes resulting in development or exacerbation of multiple sclerosis

title: Infection Studies in Pigs and Porcine Airway Epithelial Cells Reveal an Evolution of A(H1N1)pdm09 Influenza A Viruses Toward Lower Virulence
abstract: Infection Studies in Pigs and Porcine Airway Epithelial Cells Reveal an Evolution of A(H1N1)pdm09 Influenza A Viruses Toward Lower Virulence. This paper presents a comprehensive study to explore the process by which influenza viruses evolved in pigs after emerging with pandemic potential in humans. We tested the virulence of porcine-adapted, low-virulence strains of the 2009 A(H1N1), both biochemically and through infection studies with inoculated pigs and porcine primary epithelial cells. Our results indicate that swine-adapted strains exhibit considerable divergence from their more virulent parental strain, illustrating viral adaptation to both host cell receptor specificity and immune evasiveness alongside reductions in tissue tropism and pathogenic capability. Such data can facilitate improved retrospective epidemiological surveillance while providing pertinent insight into the evolution, behavior, transmission dynamics, antigenic characteristics and prophylaxis strategies for a wide range of pathogens capable of infecting animals as well as humans.

title: Archaeal DnaG contains a conserved N-terminal RNA-binding domain and enables tailing of rRNA by the exosome
abstract: This study provides evidence for the presence of a conserved N-terminal RNA-binding domain within Aquifex pyrophilus DnaG, an archaeal form of primase. Priming and tailing are essential steps during rRNA maturation that allow correct folding of the molecule into its three-dimensional structure. Using electron microscopy, biochemical fractionation combined with transcriptomic studies on A. pyrophilus cells grown under protein synthesis-limiting conditions, we show that the N-terminal region specifically binds to mature 5S/23S rRNA molecules and protected them from degradation by RNases in vitro; moreover, it is required for efficient exosome association and 3' end formation through CCA addition. Our work reveals DnaG as a novel platform mediating the primosome assembly onto preprocessed ribonucleoprotein particles in archaea and establishes a role for it in forming correct folds of functional 25S rRNAs which facilitate their biogenesis.

title: Primary Epstein–Barr virus infection shortly after primary Cytomegalovirus infection: a case report
abstract: This study presents a unique case report of an individual who experienced primary Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection shortly after being infected with primary Cytomegalovirus (CMV). The medical history and laboratory results of the patient are discussed in this paper, along with implications for the simultaneous acquisition of two herpesvirus infections. Additionally, assessments regarding the possible mechanisms associated to both EBV and CMV were performed. Through extrapolating from our findings, future studies may benefit from further investigation into whether dual herpesvirus infections can contribute to increased susceptibility for other viruses or clinical manifestations, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as children or elderly people.

title: The use of educational technology for interactive teaching in lectures
abstract:
The educational system is constantly evolving, and modern technologies are playing a decisive role in its development. This research paper aims to explore the potential of using educational technology for interactive teaching in lectures. By evaluating the advantages, notably increased engagement of students and improved knowledge retention, this study provides evidence that educational technology can become an invaluable tool to promote a more participatory atmosphere among learners while improving learning results. 

To conduct this investigation, empirical data was gathered in two higher education institutions located in Europe which had contrasting backgrounds related to the use of technological resources during regular lectures: one institution did not adopt such practices at all and the other employed interactive solutions massively throughout their curricula. Data analysis was conducted employing qualitative methods such as interviews with professors and focus groups with students before reaching any conclusion about the efficacy of educational technology for enhancing interactivity when teaching large classes. The findings suggest that there indeed exist positive effects on student performances as well as a great propensity, both from faculty members and pupils, towards greater adoption of these technologies within university environments governed by traditional pedagogical models or paradigms.

title: Aberrant remyelination of axons after heat injury in the dorsal funiculus of rat spinal cord
abstract: This article examines evidence of the effects of heat injury on remyelination in an animal model. Specifically, we investigate aberrant remyelination patterns observed following thermal excitation to rat dorsal funiculi at laboratory settings. The findings suggest that intense temperature fluctuations can cause a shift from normal remyelination activity and result in unexpected changes to axon myelin sheaths. We draw conclusions that support the relationship between altered environmental temperatures and neural fibre repair processes.

title: Whose Art Are We Talking About?
abstract: This paper examines perceptions of authorship in the art world. Investigating both established and emerging roles held by creative individuals within an artist’s oeuvre, ‘Whose Art Are We Talking About?’ seeks to answer questions around collective versus individual production processes, ownership over artistic output, and implications for existing copyright law. By exploring the complex web of relationships at play between stakeholders involved in the production of artwork including collectors, curators and critics, a better understanding of authorship can be achieved informing future discourse on this topic.

title: Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 Influenza Community Transmission Was Established in One Australian State When the Virus Was First Identified in North America
abstract: This paper examines the timeline of pandemic (H1N1) 2009 influenza transmission in an Australian state from when the virus first appeared in North America. Our review of public health records document how community transmission began relatively soon after, contributing to a large increase in registered cases and ultimately leading to the declaration of a public health emergency. The findings suggest that local factors may have played an important role in permitting early spread and increased vulnerability prior to control measures being implemented. Ultimately, this study reveals that adequate monitoring of influenza outbreaks is crucial in preventing rapid and widespread dissemination within vulnerable populations.

title: Macrophage activation syndrome in a patient with axial spondyloarthritis on adalimumab
abstract: This article examines the case of a patient with axial spondyloarthritis who, following treatment with adalimumab, developed a severe manifestation of macrophage activation syndrome. The aim was to describe this rare and potentially serious clinical complication in the setting of an immune-mediated disease treated by biologic therapies. This study highlights the relevance of determining risk factors associated with MAS occurrence even after initiation of anti-tumor necrosis factor therapies.

title: Optimization of surgical timing of congenital diaphragmatic hernia using the quantified flow patterns of patent ductus arteriosus
abstract: This paper explores the effects of early surgical timing of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) on patient outcomes. Through a comprehensive review of clinical evidence, we seek to identify the optimal timing for such procedures by quantifying flow patterns in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Our findings suggest that recognition and management of PDA in CDH cases can optimize surgery timing and yield positive longterm results; however, further research is needed across a variety of clinical scenarios to fully establish best practice standards. The implications are broad as an understanding and implementation of these proposed practices may enhance post-surgical recovery rates among this population. Optimization Of Surgical Timing Of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Using The Quantified Flow Patterns Of Patent Ductus Arteriosus

title: The Effect of School Psychologists and Social Workers on School Achievement and Failure: A National Multilevel Study in Chile
abstract: This study examines the relationship between school psychologists, social workers and student achievement in Chile based on a national multilevel approach. School-level variables such as student to staff ratios, classroom size and type of management are taken into account through data from Ministry of Education databases. By employing logistic regression analyses we observe how school-level predictors interact with individual characteristics like gender, socioeconomic position and ethnicity. The results show that both school psychologists and social workers present a positive effect on academic achievement among Chilean students at different educational levels during the period 2003–2017. Moreover, findings indicate that having access to adequate psychological or social support can attenuate the risk factors associated with school failure in this region of South America. This is one of the first studies conducted for linking resources provided by mental health professionals and their impact on closing equity gaps related to pupil outcomes in Latin America countries where accurate data have not been previously accessible until now.

title: The CD1 family and T cell recognition of lipid antigens
abstract: The CD1 family of proteins has long been known to be involved in the recognition and presentation of lipid antigens by T-cells. This study examined the relationship between human CD1a, -d and -e molecules and T-cell responses in response to a panel of synthetic bicyclic mycobacterial glycolipids (BMGLs). The results revealed structural similarities amongst BMGLs that were recognized specifically by different combinations of the three different human CD1 molecules and subsequently triggered IFN-γ secretion from specific subsets of lipid reactive T cells. Overall, this research highlights both differences and commonalities among the members of the CD1 family which have implications for understanding how these molecules discriminate pathogen lipids from self lipids during an immune response.

title: The Nonhuman Primate as a Model for Biomedical Research
abstract: This article discusses the utilization of nonhuman primates as animal models in biomedical research. Primates have been largely studied due to their close evolutionary proximity to humans, and they are particularly beneficial because they share similar physiological traits. This allows researchers to better understand how diseases manifest within human populations, evaluate potential treatments, and gain insights into a species' overall health status. Through comprehensive investigations of these animals in both captive and free-ranging settings, scientists can gain an expanded appreciation and understanding of complex biological processes that are shared between primates and humans alike. Ultimately, this paper seeks to assess the value of nonhuman primates; specifically focusing on their range of applications within the field of biomedical science.

title: Diaphragm and Lung Ultrasound Indices in Prediction of Outcome of Weaning from Mechanical Ventilation in Pediatric Intensive Care Unit
abstract: This paper presents the findings of a prospective observational study that aimed to investigate the potential utility of diaphragm and lung ultrasound indices in predicting mechanical ventilation outcomes for patients in pediatric intensive care units. The results indicated that particular transthoracic transmission measure parameters could predict successful weaning from mechanical ventilation at an earlier stage than traditional clinical assessments. Additionally, the study discussed certain risk factors associated with unsuccessful weaning and shed light on opportunities for improvement in patient care. The data generated is valuable to clinicians as it highlights how ultrasound can be utilized to identify early signs of respiratory distress, aid decision making and potentially facilitate better treatment strategies.

title: Vaccination with single plasmid DNA encoding IL-12 and antigens of severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome virus elicits complete protection in IFNAR knockout mice
abstract: This study investigates the suppressive efficacy of exercising recombinant DNA technology for inducing immune responses to shield mice from severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome virus (SFTSV). Specifically, a single plasmid encoding interleukin-12 (IL-12) and antigens of SFTSV aim to protect IFNAR knockout mice by promoting antigen antibody response. The vaccine was prepared in vitro before injection into the experimental animals three times at minimal concentrations. Following transfection and observation, researchers discovered full protection of the study organisms against SFTSV infection. Thus, this preliminary trial established an encouraging outlook for complex viral threats susceptible to IL-12 vaccination combined with antigens aimed at specific strains and pathogens.

title: Regulated Ire1-dependent decay of messenger RNAs in mammalian cells
abstract: This study explores the role of Regulated Ire1-dependent decay (RIDD) in controlling messenger RNAS (mRNAs) in mammalian cells. The pathway is critical for cellular adaptation, as illustrated by its involvement with various pathways and diseases. To investigate this phenomenon, the authors employed a variety of experimental assays to examine mRNA degradation and piece together how it occurs through regulated Ire1-dependent decay. The results uncovered that RIDD stabilizes mRNAs in prevalent environmental stresses while allowing rapid response to other cues. This study provides insight into the fine balance between stability and dynamics that controls diverse responses at the level of individual cell's transcriptome landscape.

title: CD13 promotes mesenchymal stem cell-mediated regeneration of ischemic muscle
abstract:
"CD13 promotes Mesenchymal Stem Cell-mediated Regeneration of Ischemic Muscle"
This study investigates the role of CD13 in regenerative responses to ischemic injury in muscle tissue. Specifically, it examines whether co-incubation of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) with CD13 can enhance their homing capability and differentiation potential for repairing necrotic tissues when compared to MSCs without CD13 addition. Using a mouse model for hind limb ischemia, this study determines that, at 8 weeks post-ischemia induction, treatment with MSCs mixed with CD13 significantly reduces necrosis and fibrosis more effectively than treatment using either MSCs alone or empty vector control groups. In addition, analysis of cell markers from immunofluorescent staining shows enhanced recruitment of several cytokines and adhesion molecules including Macrophage Migration Inhibitory Factor (MIF), Interleukin 10 (IL10) and Vascular Endothelial Cadherin(VEcad). Altogether these findings demonstrate the therapeutic potential offered by modulating the level CD13 to facilitate efficient mesenchymal stem cell mediated regeneration in skeletal muscle repair after acute ischemia induced damage."

title: Self-Injury in Japanese Manga: A Content Analysis
abstract: This article examines self-injury in Japanese manga and the implications for young audiences. Utilizing a qualitative content analysis of four long-running and well-known manga, this study provides insight into how themes concerning self- injury are addressed and portrayed. The findings suggest that while these stories appear to provide no guidance on issues of risk, mental health or consequences, they do contain elements of hope through strong narrative arcs. Given the wide range of readers exposed to these works and their potential impact, further research is needed to better understand the effects such portrayals might have had on young audiences across Japan.

title: First report of molecular identification of Cystoisospora suis in piglets with lethal diarrhea in Japan
abstract: This article presents the first evidence of molecular identification of Cystoisospora suis in piglets with lethal diarrhea in Japan. The research investigated a sample of veterinarians and their reported cases across 5 regions, and revealed that C. suis had been predominately causing a major outbreak among piglets associated with high mortality rates. Data from autopsy results confirmed that samples contained the species, as well as microbiological testings from tissue sampling which also showed 100% infection rate amongst the same group. By comprehensively examining both pathological findings, this report is able to provide further insight into the epidemiology of C. suis-associated diarrheal illness among piglets in the said country and can be used for more effective diagnosis, early detection and better management strategies for these types of diseases moving forward.

title: First report of Bickerstaff’s brainstem encephalitis caused by Salmonella Dublin: a case report
abstract: This case report presents the first successful account of a patient with Bickerstaff's Brainstem Encephalitis caused by Salmonella Dublin. Our objective was to assess the clinical features and its response to treatment in patients infected with this bacterium. A 62 year-old female patient exhibiting symptoms consistent with those of encephalitis visit an outpatient department at our tertiary care hospital in New Delhi, India. Radiological imaging confirmed the diagnosis along with serological findings for Salmonella Dublin. The patient responded well after being treated through combination therapy of antibiotics and supportive measures such as anti-emetic drugs and intravenous fluids. We discuss the unique characteristics of this rare disease entity along existing literature available on it and its relationship to other neurological infections such as enteric fever; also overviewing possible preventive strategies.

title: A new kind of beat
abstract: This study examines how introducing a new type of rhythmic structure affects the tempo, complexity and enjoyment of musical compositions. The 'new kind' beat uses four beats to introduce structural variety compared to prevailing six beats in popular music styles. Results reveal significant positive influences on tempo stability as well as music complexity and listener appreciation.

title: Design, Screening, and Testing of Non-Rational Peptide Libraries with Antimicrobial Activity: In Silico and Experimental Approaches
abstract: This study presents an exploration of non-rational bioactive peptide libraries with enhanced antimicrobial activities through a combination of in silico and experimental approaches. Designing, screening, and testing agents such as these have emerged as promising new avenues for the development of novel therapeutic agents that can mitigate bacterial resistance to existing drugs. Specifically, this paper introduces a powerful computational method for designing peptide libraries coupled with data mining tools to identify candidate biosurfactants using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis to validate their effectiveness against various drug-resistant bacteria strains. To effectively evaluate the reliability and efficacy of any proposed treatment library derived from these processes, extended vitro and vivo studies are also carried out on target pathogens. Finally, this report describes results obtained thus far in terms of hit rate validation metrics in relation to all known quantitative bioactive parameters involved, particularly those associated with antibacterial response evaluation.

title: Ginseng Stem-Leaf Saponins in Combination with Selenium Promote the Immune Response in Neonatal Mice with Maternal Antibody
abstract: The study of immune resistance factors is a constantly growing field in medical research. A new and promising development lies at the intersection between traditional Chinese herbal medicine and modern pharmacological techniques: ginseng stem-leaf saponin (GSL) in combination with Selenium (Se). This paper investigates the efficacy of a GSL & Se supplement to promote an immunological response under specific conditions – specifically, in neonatal mice with maternal antibodies. For this experiment, thirty pregnant female CD-1 mice were fed an experimental diet supplemented by GSL & Se for three weeks prior to giving birth; thirty control group mice were given regular diets without any supplementation. The results show that following 14 days after birth, the supplemented cohort had higher levels of both lymphocytes and serum cytokines than their counterparts from the control group mothers. Overall, results suggest that dietary supplementation of GSL & Se promotes an enhanced early immune system response among newborns carrying maternal antibodies due to modified antigen exposure during gestation.

title: Nonhuman primate to human immunobridging to infer the protective effect of an Ebola virus vaccine candidate
abstract: This paper provides an assessment of the potential protective effect of a novel candidate Ebola virus vaccine in humans by assessing its performance when administered to nonhuman primates. The study utilized an immunobridging protocol based on current United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) guidance in order to assess cross-reactivity between species-specific antibody responses, which serve as major indicators for protection from infection. Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assays (ELISA), Neutralization assays (NAs), and T Cell Responses were used to measure humoral and cellular immune responses respectively. Results suggest that despite differences in innate immunity across species, a robust humoral response was detected against the crude viral antigen post vaccination among the test subjects indicating promising efficacy for the tested vaccine candidate for further development assessments with FDA approval.

title: Structural basis of West Nile virus neutralization by a therapeutic antibody
abstract: This paper presents the first crystal structure of a complex between West Nile virus (WNV) and an anti-WNV therapeutic antibody, revealing the structural basis for neutralization through lock-and-key interactions. WNV is an emerging pathogen that has caused numerous outbreaks worldwide since its emergence in Romania in 1996. It is a mosquito borne flavivirus that can cause severe illness, culminating in death or long-term neurological effects such as encephalitis or meningitis. Therapeutic antibodies offer promising prospects for treatment against viral infections but understanding how they accomplish neutralizing activity remains elusive. Here we report on the co-crystal structure of WNV free virus and a human monoclonal IgG1 antibody targeting one of its envelope glycoproteins (E), demonstrating specific contacts enabling recognition and neutralization of infectious particles with implications for vaccine design strategies against this global threat .

title: The influence of time to adrenaline administration in the Paramedic 2 randomised controlled trial
abstract: The present study investigated the influence of time to adrenaline administration on outcomes in patients receiving prehospital advanced life support treatment. In 2020, a multi-centre, randomised controlled trial (RCT) was conducted to assess if early and timely administration of adrenaline had an impact on patient outcomes. This Paramedic 2 trial randomly assigned ventricular fibrillation (VF) cardiac arrest survivors across eight clinical sites in the United Kingdom to receive or not receive intramuscular doses of adrenaline within five minutes from when resuscitation was initiated by paramedics. The primary outcome measure was survival with a favourable neurological status at 30 days after hospital admission; secondary measures included return of spontaneous circulation and survival up to 12 months following VF cardiac arrest. Findings suggested that there were no differences between groups in terms of 30 day survival rates or 12 month mortality. However, participants who received earlier doses of adrenaline exhibited significantly improved rates for return of spontaneous circulation compared with those treated later — indicating that time has an important role in determining beneficial outcomes following prehospital treatments involving adrenaline administration during resuscitations from VF cardiac arrests..

title: Surfactant replacement therapy in acute respiratory distress syndrome from viral pneumonia
abstract: This study explores the efficacy of surfactant replacement therapy in treating acute respiratory distress syndrome from viral pneumonia (ARDS-VP). Through a prospective, observational cohort study, we assess changes induced by exogenous surfactant administration in non-ventilated and ventilated ARDS-VP patients. Results indicate that early institution of surfactant therapy is linked to improved patient outcomes such as increased lung compliance, faster resolution of oxygenation problems, decreased length of mechanical ventilation, and shorter hospital stays. These data demonstrate that exogenous surfactant administration may be beneficial for treating adults with severe ARDS-VP.

title: The effect of adjuvants on vaccine-induced antibody response against influenza in aged mice
abstract: This study tested the effects of adjuvants on vaccine-induced antibody responses against influenza in aged mice. Aging is a major risk factor associated with decreased immunogenicity and increased morbidity related to acute viral respiratory infections, such as influenza. Adjuvants are components that are added to vaccines for enhancing the effectiveness of immunization; however, little is known about how their effectiveness may be modulated by age-associated immune senescence in elderly individuals. This research analyzed the effect of two different adjuvants (Alhydrogel and CpG) on serum levels of IgG antibodies from elderly mice receiving an Influenza virus challenge after vaccination via intramuscular injection. Results suggest that pre-existing immunity can impact the response elicited by adjuvant addition, raising important implications for older people's health strategies during seasonal influenza epidemics worldwide.

title: Interleukin-22 level is negatively correlated with neutrophil recruitment in the lungs in a Pseudomonas aeruginosa pneumonia model
abstract: This study seeks to evaluate Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection-induced lung neutrophil recruitment and interleukin-22 (IL-22) production in a murine model. Previously, IL-22 has been implicated as an important regulator of P. aeruginosa associated immune defense. However, its role in pulmonary pathogenesis remains unclear despite recent advances in understanding the epigenetic signatures associated with PD support a potential role for this cytokine during this infectious process. The main objective is to assess whether levels of IL-22 are negatively correlated with neutrophil influx into the lungs following intranasal challenge with P. aeruginosa PAO1 cells or lipopolysaccharide (LPS). Findings from these experiments demonstrate that there is indeed a correlation between increased IL-22 concentrations and decreased levels of neutrophil infiltration at 2 hours post infection in mice infected by either wild type or attenuated P. aeruginosa strains compared to those observed after LPS challenge alone. Together, our results point toward an importance of IL‑22 dysregulation during Pulmonary Pseudomonas infections likely favoring suppression of innate immune cell responses within the airways microbiome affecting downstream host defense outcomes ultimately promoting bacterial persistence and consequent progression towards chronicity of conditions such as pseudomoniasis pneumoniae - A Cross Sectional Study Investigating Interleukin‑ 22 Level Correlation With Neutrophil Recruitment In The Lungs Of A Murine Model Of Pneumonia Caused By Pseudomonas Aeruginosa Infection

However, its role in pulmonary pathogenesis remains unclear despite recent advances in understanding the epigenetic signatures associated with PD support a potential role for this cytokine during this infectious process. The main objective is to assess whether levels of IL-22 are negatively correlated with neutrophil influx into the lungs following intranasal challenge with P. aeruginosa PAO1 cells or lipopolysaccharide (LPS). Findings from these experiments demonstrate that there is indeed a correlation between increased IL-22 concentrations and decreased levels of neutrophil infiltration at 2 hours post infection in mice infected by either wild type or attenuated P. aeruginosa strains compared to those observed after LPS challenge alone. Together, our results point toward an importance of IL‑22 dysregulation during Pulmonary Pseudomonas infections likely favoring suppression of innate immune cell responses within the airways microbiome affecting downstream host defense outcomes ultimately promoting bacterial persistence and consequent progression towards chronicity of conditions such as pseudomoniasis pneumoniae - A Cross Sectional Study Investigating Interleukin‑ 22 Level Correlation With Neutrophil Recruitment In The Lungs Of A Murine Model Of Pneumonia Caused By Pseudomonas Aeruginosa Infection

title: Infections in neutropenic patients I: Aetiology
abstract: This study provides an insight into the aetiology of infections in neutropenic patients. The effects of neutropenia on patient vulnerability, risk factors specific to immunocompromised individuals and infection sources are evaluated. Research on how to identify which infections these patients are most susceptible to is also explored. By understanding the principal causes of infection, healthcare providers may work towards effective prevention measures and improved outcomes for this at-risk population.

title: T cell sensitization to proteolipid protein in myelin basic protein-induced relapsing experimental allergic encephalomyelitis
abstract: This paper investigates the role of T cells in sensitizing to proteolipid protein (PLP) expressed in myelin basic protein-induced relapsing experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (R-EAE). Using a murine model, we demonstrate that R-EAE is associated with an increased frequency of central nervous system-infiltrating T cells sensitized to PLP, providing evidence that these pathogenetic responses are key elements in the development and maintenance of disease activity. Furthermore, we also assess antigenic structure as part of our investigation into PLP sensitivity during R-EAE initiation and establishment.

title: Preoperative Immunonutrition vs. Standard Dietary Advice in Normo-Nourished Patients Undergoing Fast-Track Laparoscopic Colorectal Surgery
abstract: This study examines the efficacy of preoperative immunonutrition compared to standard dietary advice in normo-nourished patients undergoing laparoscopic colorectal surgery. In recent decades, advances in surgical science have enabled fast-track colorectal surgeries with accelerated patient recovery. However, certain factors can delay wound healing and impede a successful operation. It is well documented that malnutrition has an adverse effect on postoperative outcomes. Therefore, it is increasingly important to optimize nutritional status prior to surgery by implementing strategies including preoperative nutrition counseling and specialized diets tailored to the surgical procedure. This study aims to compare the effects of Preoperative Immunonutrition versus Standard Dietary Advice on clinical outcome in Normo-Nourished Patients Undergoing Fast-Track Laparoscopic Colorectal Surgery performed between October 2018 and March 2020 at Shengjing Hospital Affiliated Shandong University Medical College China

title: Multiple lung abscesses due to acinetobacter infection: a case report
abstract: This case report presents the clinical course of a patient with multiple lung abscesses caused by Acinetobacter infection. A 50-year-old male presented with severe pneumonia, breathlessness and febrile episodes to our hospital. Investigations revealed widespread pulmonary infiltrates organized as multiple chest abscesses, due to multidrug resistant reactivation of a latent Acinetobacter baumannii infection. The patient was successfully treated with targeted antibiotics following fluid drainage of the chest abscesses using video assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS). This study highlights the importance in recognizing unusual manifestations of acinetobacter infection for prompt diagnosis and successful treatment.

title: Prevention of Pain During Screening for Retinopathy of Prematurity: A Randomized Control Trial Comparing Breast Milk, 10% Dextrose and Sterile Water
abstract: This randomized control trial assessed the effectiveness of 10% dextrose, sterile water and breast milk in reducing pain experienced during screening for retinopathy in premature infants. Pain induced by an ophthalmoscope may cause distress, leading to unreliable assessments; thus identifying alternative preventative measures is important to reduce pain and improve outcome accuracy. Following consent from caregivers, 140 preterm infants with a gestational age at birth equal or between 24-32 weeks were randomized into four groups: 1) 10% Dextrose instillation liquid 2) Sterile Water instillation liquid 3) Breast Milk 4

title: Detection of Bocavirus in Children Suffering from Acute Respiratory Tract Infections in Saudi Arabia
abstract: This paper presents a study of the detection of Bocavirus in children suffering from acute respiratory tract infections (ARIs) within Saudi Arabia. The prevalence and genetic diversity of airborne Bocaviruses associated with ARIs among paediatric patients attending hospitals within Saudi Arabia were investigated to better understand the impact of these viruses on public health. Using real-time PCR, samples collected from participants were tested for seven known strains with confirmatory sequencing being conducted when necessary. Results showed that total detection rate was 14%, with two new genotypes identified; This provides evidence supporting the role these viruses play as one of many infectious agents impacting human health in this region. Implications relating to prophylactic measures and future research around airborn viral pathogens will be discussed.

title: Extracorporeal Life Support: Four Decades and Counting
abstract: This paper presents an overview of the four decades of advancements in Extracorporeal Life Support (ECLS) technology and its application in modern cardiac care. ECLS, a technology originally developed for short-term stabilization during heart failure, has evolved into an effective long-term treatment option when coupled with medical management. The technological advances since its inception have enabled its use to treat both acute and chronic cardiac conditions. This review summarizes key developments that accelerated progress in the field over the past forty years and highlights current clinical indications supported by evidence-based research findings. Additionally, opportunities to continue improving outcomes through further technological improvements are discussed.

title: Construct validity, test-retest reliability, and the ability to detect change of the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure in a spinal cord injury population
abstract: This article examines the construct validity, test-retest reliability and change detecting ability of the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) when used within a spinal cord injury (SCI) population. To assess COPM’s accuracy among this population, studies were conducted through both qualitative interview data collection as well as quantitative testing methods to measure performance with activities of daily living (ADL). The results from these tests compared with one another in order to ascertain whether or not the COPM poses valid diagnostic implications and demonstrated satisfactory levels of repeatability. Additionally, change scores across successive assessments were computed to determine if any progresses/regressions over time could be accurately detected using this tool. Results showed that the COPM appears to have good face validity among SCI patients concerning their judgment on what tasks are important for occupational performance, along with acceptable test-retest reliability and acceptable detectability of smaller changes in ADL functioning over successive evaluations.

title: Aldosterone-induced kidney injury is mediated by NFκB activation
abstract: The kidney is a key organ responsible for several physiological functions, including electrolyte and water balance. Aldosterone-induced kidney injury has been increasingly recognized as an important contributing factor to the pathogenesis of numerous chronic diseases. In this article, we investigate whether the activation of the transcription factor NFκB plays a role in mediating aldosterone-induced kidney damage. To this end, we established an in vitro renal cell model system and explored its biochemical responses after treatment with various concentrations of aldosterone. Ultimately, our results provide evidence that NFκB is activated during aldosterone-induced injury and thus contributes to cellular stress and apoptosis associated with tissue damage in renal cells. Our data also suggest that NFκB may represent an attractive therapeutic target in order to attenuate or even halt aldosterone-induced kidney damages.

title: Pigs test positive for bird flu
abstract: This paper presents the findings of a new study confirming that pigs have tested positive for bird flu. Through lab testing, we show that H5N1 can infect swine and hence poses a potential threat to animal and human health. We then discuss the implications of these results and suggest public health responding actions in light of our discoveries.

title: A Soluble Version of Nipah Virus Glycoprotein G Delivered by Vaccinia Virus MVA Activates Specific CD8 and CD4 T Cells in Mice
abstract: This paper examines the immunogenicity of a soluble form of Nipah virus glycoprotein G delivered by Vaccinia virus MVA in terms of activating specific CD8 and CD4 T cells in mice. We present an extensive analysis demonstrating that MVA-G effectively induces both humoral immune responses and cell-mediated immunity, which can be further potentiated with adjuvant formulations or recombinant human cytokines. Additionally, it was found that the magnitude of expansion and survival rate were higher for antigen-specific T cells than non-specific ones when challenged with wild Nipah virus. Our findings provide evidence that could lead to the development of improved vaccines against Nipah infection.

title: Antibody-Based HIV-1 Vaccines: Recent Developments and Future Directions: A summary report from a Global HIV Vaccine Enterprise Working Group
abstract: This paper presents a summary of the findings from a Global HIV Vaccine Enterprise Working Group outlining recent developments and future directions in antibody-based HIV-1 vaccines. It highlights fundamental insights related to design, prospects for improved efficacy, critical questions that have emerged and highlighted viewpoints on desired outcomes along with considerations for vaccine development timelines.

title: α-mangostin preserves hepatic microvascular architecture in fibrotic rats as shown by scanning electron microscopy of vascular corrosion casts
abstract: This study provides the first detailed evidence that α-mangostin can inhibit liver fibrosis in rats by preserving the microvascular architecture of their livers. Using scanning electron microscopy of vascular corrosion casts, this paper examines how hepatic microvascular structure is preserved when supplemented with α-mangostin in a rat model of hepatic fibrosis induced by carbon tetrachloride (CCl4). Results show that using α-mangostin for treatment significantly reduced matrix deposition and restrained the thinning of hepatic sinusoid lumens as well as obliterated vasculature – thus inducing significant protection from CCl4-induced liver fibrosis. Furthermore, three weeks after cessation of treatment, effects were still observed at both macroscopic and microscopic levels; additionally demonstrating the major protective action achieved with alpha mangostin supplementation against established hepatitis containing fibrotic changes. Therefore, it is suggested that oral administration of alpha mangostin to an animal model may be able to prevent or delay progression toward cirrhosis in various forms of chronic active hepatitis and similar conditions involving activated stellate cells leading to scarring and eventual organ failure.

title: The behaviour in vitro of attenuated recombinant influenza viruses
abstract: This article summarizes the findings of an in vitro research conducted to analyse the behaviour of attenuated recombinant influenza viruses. During the investigation, results indicating a low rate of susceptibility for both human primary cells and heterologous target species were obtained. The observed evidence suggested that highly attenuated recombinants can retain certain levels of virulence, whereas other such as those containing deletions within their genomic structures were found to be inefficient at causing infections. Furthermore, secondary amplification capacities were also explored by evaluating established replicons with inserts outside predetermined epitopes which produced varied outcomes depending on strain type and alternative additives that may be incorporated during propagation or delivery processes. Altogether these observations suggest potential capabilities for using these genetically altered agents in therapeutic or prophylactic applications alongside further safety assessments in vivo.

title: Barriers, facilitators, preferences and expectations of joint protection programmes for patients with hand arthritis: a cross-sectional survey
abstract: This study introduces an investigation into the factors associated with access to, utilization of and preferences for joint protection programmes (JPPs) among patients with hand arthritis. A cross-sectional survey was conducted to assess how the socio-demographic characteristics and disease severity level may be informing patients’ perceptions on JPPs, as well as the barriers or facilitators that may impede their ability to engage with these programmes. This paper focuses on uncovering what patient preferences and expectations are in relation to such interventions and hopes to bring new insights for improving practice in this area. 269 words

title: Therapeutic Potential of the Gut Microbiota in the Management of Sepsis
abstract: This paper explores the potential therapeutic role that gut microbiota can play in the management of sepsis. Recent studies have identified how a dysbiosis in microflora composition plays a vital part in sepsis development and progression, uncovering novel avenues for its treatment via microbial interventions. The present article examines this phenomenon and investigates whether manipulation of gut microbiota could serve as an effective prophylactic or clinical adjunct to existing treatments of sepsis.

title: Supervised pulmonary hypertension exercise rehabilitation (SPHERe): study protocol for a multi-centre randomised controlled trial
abstract:
Supervised pulmonary hypertension exercise rehabilitation (SPHERe): a study protocol for a multi-centre randomised control trial 

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is an increasingly recognised condition characterised by increased pressure in the pulmonary artery, leading to impaired cardiac function and severe morbidity. Exercise plays a key role in managing PH symptoms and improving quality of life; however, it is not currently adopted routinely as part of routine care. The aim of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of supervised pulmonary hypertension exercise rehabilitation against usual care alone, using an international multi-centre randomised controlled strategy. This research will seek to determine whether implementation of SPHERe leads to improved clinical outcomes compared with standard care us usual at 12 months follow up. A total sample size of 114 adults (n=57/group) with mild or moderate PH will be allocated randomly between two interventions: either supervised Pulmonary Hypertension Exercise Rehabilitation (SPHERe) or Usual Care Only (UCO). Our primary outcome measures include walking distance during a 6 minute walk test; New York Heart Association functional status classification; self-reported physical impairment measured through EQ-5D questionnaire; changes related ventricular end diastolic diameter measured through echocardiogram assessments. Secondary outcomes measures include health related quality of life assessed via St George’s Respiratory Questionnaire and further enhanced patient reported experiences including impact on respiratory difficulty frequency, intensity and duration. This trial has received ethical approval from Cambridge Central Research Ethics Committee in the United Kingdom & Europe Multi Centre Research Authorisation PSMRCO - 0465

title: Association between early cerebral oxygenation and neurodevelopmental impairment or death in premature infants
abstract:
This paper explores the association between early cerebral oxygenation and neurodevelopmental impairment or death among premature infants. The study involved 387 preterm neonates, born before 31 weeks of gestational age, whose early cerebral unraction values were assessed by transcranial Doppler (TCD) at 24 to 72 hours after birth. Outcome measures included abnormal neurological status at two years corrected age based on a validated scale and mortality up to two years of follow-up. Statistical analyses were conducted using the Chi square test for categorical variables and logistic regression models adjusted by confounders for estimating odds ratios (OR). 
Results showed that prematurity with poorer prenatal growth was associated with higher risk of death or impaired neurologic outcome in multivariate analysis subsequently, lower TCD oxygenation levels below 10th percentile seem to increase 2.5 times this risk even after adjustments for numerous confounders. In conclusion, our study underscores the important negative impact of poor Early Cerebral Oxygenation on short & long-term outcomes in prematurely born preterm infants .

title: At the crossroads of autophagy and infection: Noncanonical roles for ATG proteins in viral replication
abstract: This paper explores the unexplored roles of ATG proteins in viral replication, and how they are at the intersection of autophagy and infection. We present evidence that ATG proteins can be important players in cellular defense against viruses, by revealing noncanonical mechanisms underlying host-pathogen interactions.
